html.title: Principles of writing consistent, idiomatic HTML
html.description: The following document outlines a reasonable style guide for HTML development. These guidelines strongly encourage the use of existing, common, sensible patterns. They should be adapted as needed to create your own style guide.

html.description: “Injecting SVG” – it sounds kinda complicated I know, but trust me it’s not. It’s actually super-simple! Right now you’re probably thinking “Why would you use JavaScript to inject SVG markup? What is it? And how does it work?” Let me explain.

html.title: SVG Icons FTW
html.author: Oleg Solomka
html.description: Despite the growing popularity of SVG, its time around and excellent browser support, we have a lack of good vector icon approaches. It's time to fill this gap and use SVG as icons in our web projects.

html.description: For an image format that features infinite scalability, SVG can be a surprisingly difficult format to make responsive: vector images do not adjust themselves to the size of the viewport by default.

html.description: SVG has its own set of filter effects that, when writing SVG, allow the author to combine several of these effects and apply the filter to the graphic.

html.title: How to Use SVG Patterns
html.author: Joni Trythall
html.description: SVG patterns are one of several paint options that we have for coloring the fills and strokes of shapes and text. While generally regarded as one of the more complex options, establishing a foundation and understanding the basic syntax can make more seemingly complex patterns much more obtainable.

html.description: There has been a general trend in Web development, for some years now, away from using images in designs. Only a few years ago software companies would favour using an image of a rounded corner as the best "cross-browser" solution

html.title: Our Pointless Pursuit Of Semantic Value
html.author: Divya Manian

html.title: Rethinking Responsive SVG
html.author: Ilya Pukhalski
html.description: If you haven’t seen Joe Harrison1’s responsive icons2 technique yet, you’ll most probably be impressed as much as I was when I first discovered it. In this article, I’d like to explore what we can do with SVG beyond “traditional” scalable vector graphics that are used to replace bitmap PNGs. In fact, we can see SVG as an independent module that encapsulates CSS for the customization of views as well as the responsive behavior that also encapsulates JavaScript for the interaction logic.

html.title: Resolution Independence With SVG
html.author: David Bushell
html.description: In this article, we’ll look at Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG), one of the most underused technologies in website development today.

html.title: HTML5 And The Document Outlining Algorithm
html.author: Derek Johnson

html.title: Getting Started with SVG Gradients
html.author: Joni Trythall
html.description: While there are many arguments for and against using SVG gradients over CSS gradients, for this article we will focus on how to get started with SVG gradients if this happens to best suit your needs.

html.title: Tips for Creating Accessible SVG
html.author: Léonie Watson
html.description: Scalable Vector Graphics (SVG) exists in a quantum state of accessibility. Which is to say that SVG is both accessible and inaccessible at the same time.

html.description: SVG is an image format for vector graphics. It literally means Scalable Vector Graphics. Basically, what you work with in Adobe Illustrator. You can use SVG on the web pretty easily, but there is plenty you should know.

html.title: SVG animation
html.description: Going from a static SVG to an animated SVG is a big jump, unless you want to float a balloon up the screen (even that takes a bijillion lines of code). There’s three ways to animate an SVG: CSS, native SVG animation and JavaScript. As email devs we can’t use  JavaScript, so we started with the more familiar CSS.
